IRS990.MissionDescription: The Portland Museum of Art strives to enrich the lives of people through acquisition, preservation, and interpretation of the visual arts and the Museum's architecturally significant buildings.
IRS990.Description: Educational Programs: Create outstanding educational programs and collection-based activities to inspire and enrich the lives of diverse audiences and serve as a vital cultural center for the city and region (41,000 participants in 2010).

Activity2.Description: Exhibitions and Collections: Originate outstanding exhibitions from the Museum's permanent collection and through borrowed works of art. Present traveling exhibitions that support and extend the Museum's mission. Preserve, document, and interpret eighteen-thousand objects in the collection and five architectural landmarks (140,046 visitors in 2010).

Activity3.Description: Collection Items Purchased: 72 works of art were purchased for the Museum's collections in 2010, providing new opportunities for visitors and the community to experience original work.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The art collection and library of the Museum are reflected in the plant fund at a nominal value. The cost of a collection item is recorded as a decrease in net assets when purchased. The proceeds from the sale of a collection item are recorded as an increase in net assets when sold. The collection is managed according to a policy which adheres to the standards of the American Association of Museums. The policy delineates responsibilities in such matters as Museum ethics, acquisitions, loans, care of collections, and deaccessioning. Objects held in the collection are carefully tracked and monitored. The Museum's deaccessioning policy allows for sale or trade of an object only when it is incompatible with the Museum's collecting mission and when clear and complete title to the work is confirmed. Proceeds from the sale of an object may only be applied toward collection acquisitions.

The Museum's collection is comprised of more than 17,000 objects, representing fine and decorative arts from the 18th century to the present. These holdings include paintings, sculpture, prints, photographs, glass, ceramics, furniture, silver, artists' books and other media. Works by George Bellows, Frederic Church, Stuart Davis, John Haberle, William Harnett, Marsden Hartley, Childe Hassam, Winslow Homer, Edward Hopper, Rockwell Kent, Fitz-Henry Lane, Thomas Moran, Louise Nevelson, John Frederick Peto, Maurice Prendergast, John Singer Sargent, and Andrew Wyeth, among others, showcase the unique artistic heritage of the United States and the creative culture of Maine. European traditions are represented by works from the hand of Max Beckmann, Marc Chagall, Gustave Courbet, Edgar Degas, Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres, Claude Monet, Henry Matisse, and Pierre-Auguste Renoir. The Museum is accredited by the American Association of Museums and adheres to best practices in developing and managing these works of art in the public trust.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Identifier: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Organization's intended use of endowment funds is for general operations, education, maintenance of collection and buildings, acquisition of art for the collection, wages, and other related expenses.

FundraiserActivityInformation.Activity: Detailed audit & assessment of Museum's development effort
Grant writing services and copy-editing of fundraising docs.

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: The Museum paid $1,500 for a membership fee and dues to Portland's Cumberland Club, for Mark H.C. Bessire, Director of the Museum. The Cumberland Club is adjacent to the Portland Museum of Art, and membership allows the Director to host meetings for the purpose of conducting Museum business.

Form990ScheduleLPartIV.Relationship: Family Member of Thomas Denenberg current Deputy Director and Chief Curator

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: The Organization sells contributions of securities through its investment broker. All gifts of securities are sold as soon as administratively possible.

The art collection and library of the Museum are reflected in the plant fund at a nominal value. The cost of a collection item is recorded as a decrease in net assets when purchased. The proceeds from the sale of a collection item are recorded as an increase in net assets when sold. The collection is managed according to a policy which adheres to the standards of the American Association of Museums. The policy delineates responsibilities in such matters as Museum ethics, acquisitions, loans, care of collections, and deaccessioning. Objects held in the collection are carefully tracked and monitored. The Museum's deaccessioning policy allows for sale or trade of an object only when it is incompatible with the Museum's collecting mission and when clear and complete title to the work is confirmed. Proceeds from the sale of an object may only be applied toward collection acquisitions.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 4
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization's bylaws were amended to add governance and compensation committees. For additional details, see narratives provided for Form 990, Part VI, lines 12c & 15.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Form 990 is distributed to the full board of trustees with sufficient time for each trustee to review it. The 990 is then discussed at a full meeting of the board of trustees, before the board votes to accept the 990.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: In 2010, a top priority for the Organization's trustees was to formalize its governance procedures. To that end, on May 26, 2010, the Organization's revised bylaws were approved, resulting in the establishment of a governance committee. Since that time, the governance committee has met three times and established procedures for monitoring and enforcing compliance with the Organization's policies, including the conflict of interest policy. The Organization now requires each trustee to review and sign a copy of the Organization's Code of Ethics on a yearly basis. Also on a yearly basis, each Trustee is required to complete and submit a personal information form on which any potential conflicts of interest are to be disclosed. If and when a conflict of interest is disclosed, the form is presented to the governance committee to be reviewed and addressed.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Per the Museum's Bylaws, the Executive Committee is authorized to exercise the following specific powers and duties on behalf of the Board: (a) To enter into employment with, and to terminate the employment of, the Corporation's chief executive officer (the "Director"), to negotiate and enter into employment contracts with the Director subject to final approval by the Board, to annually review the performance of the Director, to determine the Director's annual compensation adjustments and benefits adjustments, to resolve all disciplinary and other issues relating to the Director's employment; (b) To review annually the performance of any other key employees of the corporation and to resolve all disciplinary and other issues relating to such employees when such tasks are specifically delegated to the Executive Committee by the Board; In 2010 the Museum engaged an independent HR consulting firm, Maine HR Partners, LLC, to conduct a classification and compensation study of all positions at the Portland Museum of Art, including the Director and two Deputy Directors. The study included a customized salary and employee benefits survey of comparable organizations as well as other employers in the relevant market areas and other published surveys. A survey of fringe benefit practices was also conducted and the results incorporated into the final report, in order to consider total compensation in the establishment of a salary structure. Based on their analysis of market data, salary ranges were developed which address the concepts of market competitiveness and internal equity considerations. Maine HR Partners, LLC also worked with Museum staff and the Museum's Human Resources Committee to develop a performance evaluation system, which included 360 degree performance reviews of these three individuals. The Director's performance review was conducted by the Board President and reviewed with the Executive Committee. The two Deputy Directors' performance reviews were conducted by the Director and presented to the Executive Committee. Compensation for these three individuals was determined by vote of the Executive Committee utilizing the performance review data and data from the independent classification and compensation study.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization's governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are made available to the public upon request.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Changes in Net Assets or Fund Balances:

GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The audit process has not changed from the prior year.
